questions.text: Which of the following statement regarding functional differences in hemoglobin and myoglobin is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Hemoglobin has a quaternary structure and myoglobin lacks a quaternary structure

options.label: B
options.text: Myoglobin is saturated at normal PO 2 in skeletal muscle and releases O 2 only when tissue becomes hypoxic, making it a good O 2 -storage protein

options.label: C
options.text: Hb has low O 2 affinity at high PO 2 (in lungs) and high O 2 affinity at low PO 2 in tissues), helping it to unload oxygen in the tissues

options.label: D
options.text: Hemoglobin has four heme groups and myoglobin with one heme group

questions.correct_answer: C. Hb has low O 2 affinity at high PO 2 (in lungs) and high O 2 affinity at low PO 2 in tissues), helping it to unload oxygen in the tissues
questions.explanation:
Characteristic Haemoglobin Myoglobin
Function O2 transport O2 storage
Location In red blood cells In skeletal muscle
Amount of O2 bound at Po2 in lungs High High
Amount of O2 bound at Po2 in tissues Low High
Quaternary structure Yes (tetramer) No (monomer)
Binding curve (% saturation vs Po2) Sigmoidal (cooperative binding of multiple ligand molecules) Hyperbolic (binding of one ligand molecule in reversible equilibrium)
Number of heme groups Four One

Which of the following statement about coronary blood supply is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Left anterior descending artery and its branches supply anterior 2/3 of interventricular septum, anterolateral papillary muscle, and anterior surface of LV

options.label: B
options.text: In right dominance circulation, posterior descending artery arises from right coronary artery

options.label: C
options.text: Left coronary artery occlusion may result in SA nodal dysfunction

options.label: D
options.text: PDA supplies posterior 1/3 of interventricular septum, posterior 2/3 walls of ventricles, and posteromedial papillary muscle

questions.correct_answer: C. Left coronary artery occlusion may result in SA nodal dysfunction
questions.explanation:
Coronary blood supply

LAD and its branches supply anterior 2 / 3 of interventricular septum, anterolateral papillary muscle, and anterior surface of LV. Most commonly occluded.

PDA supplies posterior 1 / 3 of interventricular septum, posterior 2 / 3 walls of ventricles, and posteromedial papillary muscle.

RCA supplies AV node and SA node. Infarct may cause nodal dysfunction (bradycardia or heart block). Right (acute) marginal artery supplies RV.

Dominance:·

  • Right-dominant circulation (most common) = PDA arises from RCA·
  • Left-dominant circulation = PDA arises from LCX·
  • Codominant circulation = PDA arises from both LCX and RCA

Coronary blood flow to LV and interventricular septum peaks in early diastole.

questions.text: E.coli is an important causative agent of pyelonephritis in man. The property that helps the bacteria in this is most likely to be:-
questions.explanation:
Option 1
  • Adhesins: E. coli organisms possess numerous highly specialized adhesins.

These adhesins include:

  1. CFA-I, II, III
  2. Aggregative adherence fimbriae (AAF I,II,III)
  3. Bundle-forming pili (Bfp)
  4. Intimin
  5. P pili(binds to P blood group antigens)
  6. Ipa (invasion plasmid antigen) protein
  7. Dr fimbriae (bind to Dr blood group antigens).
  • All these adhesins facilitate firm adhesion of E. coli to the gastrointestinal or urinary tract mucosa, thereby preventing the bacteria being eliminated by the flushing action of voided urine or intestinal motility.
Option 2
  • Enterotoxins are important virulent factors of diarrhogenic E. coli.
  • Three distinct types of E. coli enterotoxins include :
  1. Shiga toxins (Stx-1, Stx-2)
  2. heat-stable toxins (STa and STb)
  3. heat labilet oxins (LT-I and LT-II).
Option 3
  • Hemolysins are considered important in the pathogenesis of disease caused by uropathogenic strains of E. coli.
Option 4
  • Hydrophilic capsular K antigens protect E. coli from phagocytosis, which repel the hydrophobic phagocytic cell surface. The capsular antigens interfere with the binding of antibodies to the bacteria.

Option 3

Type A is responsible for most of the cases of food poisoning
Option 4

Epidermolytic toxin (Exfoliative toxin) causes:

  1. Scalded skin syndrome (Nikolsky’s sign-epidermal layer separated). Refer to the image below.
  2. Severe- Ritter disease (newborn), toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) (adult)
  3. Milder- Pemphigus neonatorum, bullous impetigo
  • Exfoliative toxin A- encoded by beta located on a phage, is heat stable.
  • Exfoliative toxin B- plasmid mediated and heat labile.

STAPHYLOCOCCAL SCALDED SKIN SYNDROME:

  • Induced by Epidermolytic exotoxins (Exfoliative)A and B, which are released byS. aureus →detachment within the epidermal layer, by breaking down the desmosomes.

questions.text: A patient presented with complains of fever, hearing difficulty, ear pain and fluid discharge from ears. The condition was diagnosed as otitis media caused by Streptococci. Which of the following is the virulence factor of group A beta haemolytic Streptococci ?
questions.explanation:
Virulence factor of group A beta hemolytic Streptococci is M protein.

Virulence factors of Streptococcus:

  • M protein:Basis of Griffith typing,inhibits phagocytosis.
  • Lipoteichoic acid: Helps in adhesion.
  • Polysaccharide capsule.
  • Toxins:
  1. Hemolysins (Streptolysin O, Streptolysin S)
  2. Erythrogenic toxin.
  • Enzymes:
  1. Streptokinase: Facilitate spread of infection.
  2. DNAse: Serous nature of exudate.
Option 1,2,3

Cell wall antigens:

  • Inner thick peptidoglycan layer (confers cell wall rigidity, induces inflammatory response and has thrombolytic activity)
  • C-carbohydrate antigen: Present as middle layer and is group specific. Basis of Lancefield’s grouping (for β haemolytic Streptococci)
  • Outer layer of protein (M, T, R) and lipoteichoic acid (helps in adhesion)
  • M protein-Major virulence factor of S pyogenes.
Option 4 Outer layer of lipoteichoic acid: helps in adhesion.

questions.text: For the past 6 weeks, a 39-year-old male has had a painful palpable mass at his anus. The discomfort is described as throbbing, and it gets worse when you sit down. The lump is warm, erythematous, and sensitive when examined. He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DISEASE?

After being stabbed in the chest with a knife, a 46-year-old man was taken to A&E. His chest is completely clear on both sides. His heart sounds are muffled, and his neck veins appear to be distended. His blood pressure is 84/40 mmHg, and his heart rate is 110 beats per minute. What is the ONE MOST APPROPRIATE EXAMINATION THAT CAN LEAD TO A DISEASE?
questions.explanation:
Acute pericarditis Pericardial effusion Cardiac Tamponade
Cause

Causes include

  • Viral infections (coxasackie)
  • Tuberculosis
  • Uraemia
  • Trauma
  • Post-myocardial infarction, Dressler’s syndrome
  • Connective tissue disease
 Any cause of pericarditis (see left) Any cause of pericarditis (see left) but especially trauma
Clinical features Central chest pain worse on inspiration or lying flat and relieved by sitting forward Dyspnoea Raised JVP Pulse ­BP ¯Muffled heart sounds ­ JVP Beck’s triad: Falling BP, rising, JVP, muffled heart sounds
Test

ECG classically shows concave (saddle-shaped) ST segment elevation.

Troponin may be raised

CXR shows enlarged, globular heart.

ECG shows low-voltage QRS complexes and alternating

 Echo is diagnostic
Treatment NSAIDS Pericardiocentesis Urgent pericardiocentesis
